content.text: Authentication is your first line of defense in protecting ClearTriage's systems and data. Since our FedRAMP boundary includes AWS and Google Drive, we need to ensure everyone follows strict authentication procedures for these systems.

content.title: Key Point
content.text: Every access attempt to our FedRAMP systems creates an audit trail. Proper authentication ensures we know exactly who accessed what and when.
AWS contains our production infrastructure and customer data. To meet FedRAMP requirements, we enforce hardware-based multi-factor authentication for all AWS access.

content.title: Mandatory Requirement
content.text: ALL AWS access requires a FIPS-enabled YubiKey. No exceptions. This includes console access, CLI access, and programmatic access.
When you join ClearTriage or need AWS access:

items: Pete will order a FIPS-enabled YubiKey 5 Series for you
You'll receive it within 3-5 business days
Schedule a 15-minute setup session with Pete
Keep your YubiKey with you at all times when working

content.text: YubiKey authentication is straightforward once set up:

items: Navigate to AWS Console and enter your username/password
When prompted for MFA, insert your YubiKey into a USB port
Touch the gold sensor on the YubiKey when it lights up
You're now authenticated for that session

content.text: The YubiKey light will blink when it needs your touch. No codes to type or apps to open!
If you lose your YubiKey or it stops working:

items: Immediately notify Pete via Slack or phone
Pete will disable the lost YubiKey within 15 minutes
A replacement will be ordered same-day
You'll be temporarily unable to access AWS (plan accordingly)
Once received, Pete will help you register the new YubiKey

content.title: Security Note
content.text: Report lost YubiKeys immediately. Don't wait until you need AWS access. A lost YubiKey is a security incident that requires prompt action.
Our FedRAMP documentation lives in Google Drive. While not as sensitive as AWS, these documents still require proper authentication.

content.title: MFA Required
content.text: Multi-factor authentication is mandatory for all Google accounts accessing FedRAMP documentation. You must use an approved authenticator app.
You may use any of these authenticator apps:

items: **Google Authenticator** - Simple and reliable, works on iOS/Android
**Authy** - Includes cloud backup capabilities
**Keeper** - If you're already using Keeper for password management

content.title: Not Approved
content.text: SMS/text message codes are NOT approved for FedRAMP. You must use an authenticator app.

items: Go to myaccount.google.com/security
Click on "2-Step Verification"
Choose "Authenticator app" (not phone/SMS)
Scan the QR code with your chosen app
Enter the 6-digit code to verify
Save the backup codes somewhere secure (like Keeper)

content.title: Pro Tip from Experience
content.content: When you set up MFA, immediately test it by logging out and back in. Better to catch issues during setup than when you urgently need access to documentation.

content.text: Once MFA is set up, logging in is simple:

items: Enter your Google email and password
Open your authenticator app
Enter the 6-digit code shown for your Google account
Check "Don't ask again on this computer" if it's your work machine

content.text: The codes refresh every 30 seconds. If a code isn't working, wait for the next one rather than trying multiple times.
Beyond just authentication, following these practices helps maintain our security posture:
This might seem obvious, but it bears repeating:

items: Never share your password, even with Pete or Dave
Never let someone "borrow" your YubiKey, even for a minute
Never enter credentials on someone else's computer
If someone needs access, they should request their own credentials

content.title: Real Scenario
content.content: "Hey, can I use your login real quick to check something?" The answer is always no. Direct them to Pete for proper access.

content.text: Since we're a small team in a shared space, it's easy to get comfortable. But screen locking is non-negotiable:

items: **Windows**: Windows Key + L
**Mac**: Control + Command + Q
**Linux**: Ctrl + Alt + L (usually)

content.title: Make it a Habit
content.text: Every time you stand up, lock your screen. Coffee break? Lock it. Bathroom? Lock it. Quick question from a colleague? You get the idea.
If you notice anything suspicious, report it immediately:

items: Unexpected MFA prompts when you're not logging in
Email notifications about login attempts you didn't make
Your YubiKey not working when it should
Being logged out unexpectedly
Any "account locked" messages

content.title: How to Report
content.text:
1. Take a screenshot if possible
2. Note the exact time and what you were doing
3. Immediately message Pete on Slack
4. If Pete isn't available, message Dave
5. Don't try to "investigate" yourself - let Pete handle it

content.title: What This Looks Like
content.content: "@Pete - Just got an MFA prompt on my phone but I'm not logging into anything. Screenshot attached. It's 2:47 PM."

content.title: Authentication Summary
content.text:
**AWS**: FIPS YubiKey required (hardware token)
**Google Drive**: MFA with approved app (soft token)
**Both**: Never share credentials, always lock screens, report suspicious activity immediately

Remember: authentication isn't just about compliance - it's about protecting our customers' trust and our company's reputation. Every time you properly authenticate, you're contributing to ClearTriage's security.
